section.title: Marginals and Introduction to Linear Approximations

li.p: What is the marginal Profit, Revenue, and Cost? How can we use these to approximate the Profit, Revenue, and Cost functions?
How can we use marginal Profit, Revenue, and Cost to approximate the Profit, Revenue, and Cost functions?
For a general differentiable function, how can we use the derivative of a function to approximate the values of the function?

introduction.p: Often in business, explicit formulas for Cost, Revenue, and Profit (C(x), R(x), and P(x) respectively) are not known. However, information may exist about the cost, revenue and profit trends at a particular value x=a. For example suppose that you are running a company that produces and sells computers. In an ideal world, you would have a function, P(x), for the profit from the sale of x computers. However, in the real world, you only know that the profit from the sale of 100 laptops is P(100)=\$5000. You also know that the profit increased by \$100 per laptop when 100 laptops are sold.

From this information you could make an estimate that the profit from the sale of 101 computers would be P(101)\approx 5100. It is important to note that you can not assume that the profit grows at a linear (i.e. constant) rate! There are many variables when producing and selling an item, and for many companies a profit is not made unless a certain number of units are sold.

Without creating an explicit function for the profit, can we estimate future profits? In this section we will explore how to use the derivative (or rate of change) of a function to estimate the values of the function.

subsection.title: Marginals

assemblage.title: Marginal Cost, Revenue and Profit
assemblage.p: The marginal cost is the derivative C'(x) of the cost function. If we know the cost of selling x items, then the marginal cost is used to approximate cost of x+1 or items. This is because C(x+1)-C(x)\approx C'(x), and we can solve this and give an approximation for C(x+1): C(x+1)\approx C(x)+ C'(x).

The marginal revenue is the derivative R'(x) of the revenue function. If we know the revenue from selling x items, then the marginal revenue is used to approximate revenue from selling x+1 items. This is because R(x+1)-R(x)\approx R'(x), and we can solve this and give an approximation for R(x+1): R(x+1)\approx R(x)+ R'(x).

The marginal profit is the derivative P'(x) of the profit function. If we know the profit from selling x items, then the marginal profit is used to approximate profit from selling x+1 items. This is because P(x+1)-P(x)\approx P'(x), and we can solve this and give an approximation for P(x+1): P(x+1)\approx P(x)+ P'(x).

statement.p: Suppose the monthly cost, in dollars, of producing x backpacks is C(x)=0.001x^3+0.07x^2+19x+700, and currently 25 backpacks are produced monthly.

li.p: What is the current monthly cost? What is the current marginal cost?
What would be the additional cost of increasing the production to 26 backpacks monthly?
Using the marginal cost, what is the approximate cost to produce the 26th backpack monthly? Compare this to the actual additional cost computed in part (b).
Use the marginal cost to estimate C(27), C(28), and C(23).
The approximate cost to produce the 26th item is C'(25)=24.38, the real cost is 24.52, thus the approximation is only off by 14 cents!

To find the current monthly cost, simply plug 25 into the given cost equation: C(25)=0.001(25)^3+0.07(25)^2+19(25)+700=1234.38. The marginal cost is the derivative of the cost function C'(x)=0.003x^2+0.14x+19, thus the marginal cost when 25 backpacks are produced monthly is:
The additional cost of increasing the production to 26 backpacks monthly is C(26)-C(25)=24.52.
The approximate cost to produce the 26th item is C'(25)=24.38, and the real cost is 24.52. Thus the approximation is only off by 14 cents!

To estimate the cost of producing 27 backpacks we can use: C(27)\approx C(25)+2C'(25)=1234.38+2(24.38)=1283.13. To estimate the cost of producing 28 backpacks we can use: C(28)\approx C(25)+3C'(25)=1234.38+3(24.38)=1307.51. To estimate the cost of producing 23 backpacks, which is 2 less, we can use: C(23)\approx C(25)-2C'(25)=1234.38-2(24.38)=1185.62.

statement.p:
Suppose a company finds that the weekly profit, in dollars, from selling x cars is
P(x)=-0.006x^3-0.2x^2+900x-1200.
Currently 60 cars are sold weekly.

li.p: What is the current weekly profit? What is the current marginal profit?
How much profit would be lost if the dealership were able to sell only 59 cars weekly? How does this value compare to the marginal profit found in part (a)?
Use the marginal profit to estimate the weekly profit if the sales increase to 61 cars weekly, 62 cars weekly, and 65 cars weekly.
Approximate profit when 61 cars are sold weekly is \$51595.20. Approximate profit when 62 cars are sold weekly is \$52406.40. Approximate profit when 61 cars are sold weekly is \$54840.

To find the current weekly profit, plug 60 into the given profit equation: P(60)=-0.006(60)^3-0.2(60)^2+900(60)-1200=50784. The marginal profit is the derivative of the profit function P'(x)=-0.018x^2-0.4x+900, and thus the marginal profit when 60 cars are produced weekly is:P'(60)=-0.018(60)^2-0.4(60)+900=811.20

The profit lost if the dealership were able to sell only 59 cars weekly is P(60)-P(59)=812.47. When we compare this to the marginal profit, we observe that we are only off by \$1.27, which is a very good approximation.

Approximate profit when 61 cars are sold weekly is P(61)\approx P(60)+P'(60)=\$51595.20. Approximate profit when 62 cars are sold weekly is P(62)\approx P(60)+2P'(60)=\$52406.40. Approximate profit when 61 cars are sold weekly is P(65)\approx P(60)+5P'(60)=\$54840.

subsection.p: Of course the final part of these examples are just estimates. If we have an explicit function for C(x) and P(x) in the real world, then we would never use an estimate. However, often in the real world we only have the information at a point and not an explicit function. This example demonstrates how we could approximate.

statement.p: Suppose that a company that sells widgets determines that the daily revenue, R(x), in dollars, from the sale of 75 widgets are sold is 900 dollars. The marginal revenue when 75 widgets are sold is 11 dollars per widget.

li.p: Estimate the daily revenue from the sale of 77 widgets.
Estimate the daily revenue from the sale of 80 widgets.
Estimate the daily revenue from the sale of 74 widgets.
R(80)\approx 955.

Here we are not given the revenue function. However, we are given R(75)=900 and R'(75)=11. In the real world these are values that could be computed even without ever finding an explicit revenue function. We can use this information to approximate the revenue from the sale of 77 items: R(77)\approx R(75)+2R'(75)=900+2(11)=922.
We start at 75 since this is the only information given, then we multiply the marginal revenue by 2 since we have sold 2 more widgets to get to a total of 77 widgets.

R(80)\approx R(75)+5R'(75)=900+5(11)=955.
We start at 75 since this is the only information given, then we multiply the marginal revenue by 5 since we have sold 5 more widgets to get to a total of 80 widgets.

R(74)\approx R(75)-R'(75)=900-(11)=889.
We start at 75 since this is the only information given, then we multiply the marginal revenue by -1 since we have sold 1 less widgets to get to a total of 74 widgets.

subsection.title: Linear Approximations
subsection.p: So far, we have used marginals to approximate the revenue, profit, and cost functions. The ideas that we have introduced in this section regarding marginals can be generalized to any differentiable function.

Among all functions, linear functions are simplest. One of the powerful consequences of a function y = f(x) being differentiable at a point (a,f(a)) is that up close the function y = f(x) is locally linear and looks like its tangent line at that point. In certain circumstances, this allows us to approximate the original function f with a simpler function L that is linear: this can be advantageous when we have limited information about f or when f is computationally or algebraically complicated. We will explore all of these situations in what follows.

It is essential to recall that when f is differentiable at x = a, the value of f'(a) provides the slope of the tangent line to y = f(x) at the point (a,f(a)). If we know both a point on the tangent line and the slope of the line we can find the equation of the tangent line and write the equation in point-slope form. Recall that a line with slope m that passes through (x_0,y_0) has equation y - y_0 = m(x - x_0), and this is the point-slope form of the equation.

li.p: Find the derivative g'(x).
Determine the slope of the tangent line to the graph of y = g(x) at the value x = 2.
Compute g(2).
Find an equation for the tangent line to the graph of y = g(x) at the point (2,g(2)). Write your result in point-slope form.

li.p: Since the slope of the tangent line at a point is the value of the derivative at that point, we have the slope as g'(2)=-2(2)+3=-1.
Evaluating g(x) at x=2, we find g(2)=-(2)^2+3(2)+2=4.
Using the slope of -1 that we found in part (b) together with the value g(2)=4 found in (c), the tangent line to y=g(x) at (2,4) is y-4=-1(x-2).

subsection.title: The Tangent Line
subsection.p:
Given a function f that is differentiable at x = a, we know that we can determine the slope of the tangent line to y = f(x) at (a,f(a)) by computing f'(a). This allows us to write the equation for the tangent line as follows: The Tangent Line
The equation of the resulting tangent line tangent lineequation is given in point-slope form by
y - f(a) = f'(a)(x-a) .

warning.p: Note: there is a major difference between f(a) and f(x) in this context. The former is a constant that results from using the given fixed value of a, while the latter is the general expression for the rule that defines the function. The same is true for f'(a) and f'(x): we must carefully distinguish between these expressions. Each time we find the tangent line, we need to evaluate the function and its derivative at a fixed a-value.

subsection.p: In Figure below, we see the graph of a function f and its tangent line at the point (a,f(a)). Notice how when we zoom in we see the local linearity of f more clearly highlighted. The function and its tangent line are nearly indistinguishable up close. Local linearity can also be seen dynamically in the java applet at http://gvsu.edu/s/6J.

figure.caption: The graph of a function y = f(x) and its tangent line at the point (a,f(a)): at left, from a distance, and at right, up close. If we let L(x)=f'(a)(x-a)+f(a) denote the tangent line function, then we observe in the right image that for x near a, f(x) \approx L(x).

subsection.title: The Local Linearization
subsection.p:
A slight change in perspective and notation will enable us to be more precise in discussing how the tangent line approximates f(x) near x = a. By solving for y, we can write the equation for the tangent line as
y = f'(a)(x-a) + f(a) . This line is itself a function of x. Replacing the variable y with the expression L(x), we have the following. Local Linearization
We call
L(x) = f'(a)(x-a) + f(a)
the local linearization of f local linearization tangent line approximation at the point (a,f(a)).
In this notation, L(x) is nothing more than a "new name" for the tangent line. As we saw above, for x close to a, f(x) \approx L(x). For this reason, L(x) is also called the tangent line approximation to f at (a,f(a)).

statement.p:
Suppose that all we know about a function f is that its tangent line approximation at the point (1,3) is given by L(x) = 3 - 2(x-1). To estimate a value of f(x) for x near 1, such as f(1.2), we can use the fact that f(1.2) \approx L(1.2). Hence
f(1.2) \approx L(1.2) = 3 - 2(1.2-1) = 3 - 2(0.2) = 2.6 .

example.title: Error in a Tangent Line Approximation

statement.p:
Consider the function p(t)=\ln(t).
Find the local linearization, L(t), of p at t=1.
Use the tangent line approximation from (a) to estimate the value of \ln(1.01).
Use the tangent line approximation from (a) to estimate the value of \ln(1.3).
local linearizationerror tangent line approximationerror The error of an approximation is the difference between the true value and the estimated value. In particular, given a function f and its local linearization L(x) at (a,f(a)), we say the error of the tangent line approximation is E(x)\amp=f(x)-L(x)\amp=f(x)-f(a)-f'(a)(x-a), for values of x near a.
Of the two estimates you found in (b) and (c), which do you expect to be more accurate? Why? Check your guess by calculating and comparing E(1.01) and E(1.3).

li.p: Start by finding \frac{d}{dt}[\ln(t)].
By construction of L(t), we know that p(1.01)\approx L(1.01).
Remember that p(1.3)\approx L(1.3).
The approximation should be best close to t=1. Note E(1)=0 since p(1)=L(1).
\ln(1.3)\approx0.3.

We start by computing p'(t), and then evaluating p(1) and p'(1). Since p(t)=\ln(t), the derivative is p'(t)=\frac1t. Furthermore, we have p(1)=\ln(1)=0 and p'(1)=\frac11=1. Thus, the local linearization of p(t)=\ln(t) at the point (1,0) is L(t)=p(1)+p'(1)(t-1)=0+1(t-1)=t-1.
Since we can use the tangent line approximation for p at (1,0) to estimate output values of p at nearby points, it follows that p(1.01)\approx L(1.01). Thus we have \ln(1.01)\approx0.01.
Since we can use the tangent line approximation for p at (1,0) to estimate output values of p at nearby points, it follows that p(1.3)\approx L(1.3). Thus we have \ln(1.3)\approx0.3.

Since 1.3 is farther away from the point of tangency (t=1) than 1.01 is, we expect the estimate to be better for 1.01. We confirm this by computing the error at each point, finding that
E(1.01)\amp=p(1.01)-L(1.01) \amp=\ln(1.01)-0.01 \amp\approx-0.0000497, \text{and} \ \ E(1.3)\amp=p(1.3)-L(1.3) \amp=\ln(1.3)-0.3 \amp\approx-0.0376357 . As expected, the error grew as the point moved farther from the initial point of tangency.

subsection.p:
We emphasize that L(x) is simply a new name for the tangent line function. Using this new notation and our observation that L(x) \approx f(x) for x near a, it follows that we can write
f(x) \approx f(a) + f'(a)(x-a) \ \text{for} \ x \ \text{near} \ a .

li.p: The marginal cost is the derivative C'(x) of the cost function, the marginal revenue is the derivative R'(x) of the revenue function, and the marginal profit is the derivative P'(x) of the profit function. If we know the cost of selling x items, then the marginal cost can be used to estimate the cost of selling another amount of items, if that amount is near x . The same holds true for the marginal revenue and marginal profit functions.

The tangent line to a differentiable function y = f(x) at the point (a,f(a)) is given in point-slope form by the equation
y - f(a) = f'(a)(x-a) .

For a function f which is differentiable at x=a , we can use the equation for tangent line L(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x-a) to approximate f near a . We often call L(x) the local linearization of f at a , or the tangent line approximation f at a . Marginal cost, revenue, and profit are an example of using the local linearization of the cost, revenue, and profit functions respectively to approximate these functions.
